title: RBA warns climate risks may become uninsurable
text:
"While insurers can increase their premiums to reflect higher risk, it is difficult to accurately price new and uncertain climate risks. If insurers underprice these risks, it could threaten their viability in the event of extreme weather events resulting in very large losses."

On the other hand, it said overpricing the risk would "impede the risk pooling function provided by insurance and unduly limit economic activity".

"Even if correctly priced, more of these [climate change] risks may become uninsurable, forcing households, businesses or governments to bear this risk," the RBA warns. Getty Images

"Even if correctly priced, more of these risks may become uninsurable, forcing households, businesses or governments to bear this risk," the paper warns.

Investors, meanwhile, could suffer from "sudden or unexpected" regulatory change that could leave businesses unviable, creating stranded assets.

"Such regulatory changes could either be domestic or come from abroad, given the carbon intensity of Australia's exports. Transition risk could also arise if large investment in technologies allowed new entrants to displace established but emissions-intensive practices, or if consumer preferences shifted rapidly towards ‘green’ products," it read.

Directors would face legal risk if they failed to address the potential exposure of their firms to climate-related risks, the paper warns, referring to the Hutley opinion, in which Sydney SC Noel Hutley, and barrister Sebastian Hartford Davis, concluded there were "significant and well publicised risks associated with climate change and global warming that would be regarded by a court as foreseeable".

Climate risk was "not yet a significant threat to financial stability in Australia", the RBA said, though adding it was "becoming increasingly important for investors and institutions to take account of and manage these risks".

It warned of the inherent uncertainty of these risks, compounded by the "significant" lack of data available to assess them

"To manage their own direct exposure to physical risk, insurers and banks need granular information on the location and physical risks faced by the assets they insure or the collateral they lend against," the report says.

"But they also need to consider their indirect exposure to firms or individuals that may be exposed to climate risk, which is challenging because of firms' incomplete or inconsistent climate-related financial risk disclosure."

The RBA gave favourable mention to the international private-sector led Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures, and also mentioned the work done on climate risk by its fellow financial regulators, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC).

It also said it was "involved in international efforts to improve regulators' understanding of the implications of climate change for the financial sector", including through the Network for Greening the Financial System, a group of central banks and supervisors.
description: The Reserve Bank of Australia warns changing weather patterns could lead to some risks becoming uninsurable in a climate-change risk report.
